comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
This is a most interesting photograph. The two buildings in the background were demolished in the early years of the twentieth century (1922 [?] needs to be confirmed) thus extending the 'plaza' which now forms that end of the quay. During the renovations the whole area along that (the western) side of Circular Quay was opened up, the tramways rerouted and the current "configuration" of streets created, spoilt, many would say (a former PM included) by the addition of the Circular Quay railway and Cahill Expressway in the 1950s.

The building on he corner of Barton and George Streets is a fire station - I love the tower - but I'm not sure what the other building housed. Others will I'm sure!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] It is the Sydney Harbour Trust Building (1903?) - I think it was demolished to make the Cahill Expressway in the 1950s (?). See comments here - trying to work out the order in which the four photos were taken - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/2715092837/] also investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... and investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... I think the REAL subject of all four photos is the newly-completed Sydney Harbour Trust Building, as a record for the Government Printing Office and what became the Ports Authority / MSB.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: Thanks Beachcomber, somewhere in papers I have a record of when the Harbour Trust Building  was demolished ... I'll do some research and advise, but i don't think it was as late as the 50s.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The Sydney Harbour Trust Building was opened on 23/12/1903 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14588818 . And demolished in October 1954 - SMH 10/10/1954 (with pictures!) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/18457711 The 'Lady Hopetoun' was launched in 1902 - www.shf.org.au/LdyHpt/LdyHpt.html

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: Thanks, I stand corrected! I got that wrong.

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: There is a picture I have seen which looks east towards Circular Quay showing the alignment of the Circular Quay railway before they built the bridge section over George Street. The Sydney Harbour Trust building and the fire station were still standing. It shows the railway was to pass about a metre south of the fire station and there was no physical need to demolish it. Both buildings were on a different alignment to the railway and part of the Harbour Trust building was in the way.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: This can't be looking east.   The photographer is in Circular Quay on a ferry and is looking roughly south-west.    These buildings were in the vicinity of the current "First Fleet Park"

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: "There is a picture I have seen looking east....."     not this picture. I was referring to another picture I have seen that shows the alignment of these buildings to the new railway.

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content:
Here is the photo I was talking about. The Circular Quay railway about to cross George Street and plough through both the Circular Quay Fire Station at left, and the Harbour Trust building dead ahead. To the right of the (rear of the) Harbour Trust building you can see the Paragon Hotel, Customs House, and Morts Bond stores in the distance.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/63385174@N06/6143366156/in/photostream]

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/63385174@N06] Thanks for adding this other view; great to see another angle.

AB
